page.title: 07CATTLE FARMING NEAR HOWNAM
page.content: The farm,which is near Hownam, is run as a beef enterprise,and worked as a family unit. To utilise the necessary machinary,agricultural contract work is carried out. The farm is all under grass with about one quarter being made into big bale silage each summer. Direct re-seeding is carried out when necessary.Cows are put to Charollais bulls and calved in the spring.These, plus additional reared calves are taken through to finishing weights at 18 months.Cattle are all in-wintered in sheds,the straw needed for feeding and bedding is purchased and baled further down Tweedside,and transported onto the farm.The muck from the sheds is put in a midden to rot before being spread on the silage feilds after the crop is cleared.This system works well as the land is mostly fairly steep and is unsuitable for arable cash crops.
